questions.qText: The Henry’s law constant for the solubility of \(N_2\) gas in water at 298 K is \(1.0 \times 10^5\) atm. The mole fraction of \(N_2\) in air is 0.8. The number of moles of \(N_2\), from air dissolved in 10 moles of water at 298 K and 5 atm pressure is

At a particular temperature and at a pressure of 1 atm, the mass and volume of \(O_3\) that can be dissolved in 1 L of \(H_2O\) is ‘m’ gram and ‘V’ ml, respectively. Assuming that the solution obeys Henry’s law, the mass and volume of \(O_3\) dissolved in 2 L of water at the same temperature and at 5 atm will be

The vapour pressure of a substance of low volatility can be measured by passing an unreactive gas over a sample of the substance and analysing the composition of the resulting gas mixture. When nitrogen was passed over mercury at 23\(^{\circ}\)C, the mixture was analysed to 0.8 mg of Hg, 50.4 g of nitrogen at a total pressure of 720 torr. The vapour pressure of mercury at this temperature is (Hg = 200)

A beaker (A) contains 20 g of sugar in 100 g water. Another beaker (B) contains 10 g of sugar in 100 g water. Both the beakers are placed under a bell jar and allowed to stand until equilibrium is reached. How much water will be transferred from one beaker to the other? Neglect the mass of water vapour present at equilibrium.
qOptions: 33.33 g water will transfer from beaker–A to beaker–B.
33.33 g water will transfer from beaker–B to beaker–A.
50.00 g water will transfer from beaker–B to beaker–A.

questions.qText: Liquids A and B form an ideal solution. The plot of \(\dfrac{1}{X_A}\) (Y-axis) versus \(\dfrac{1}{Y_A}\) (X-axis) (where \(X_A\) and \(Y_A\) are the mole fractions of A in liquid and vapour phases at equilibrium, respectively) is linear whose slope and intercept, respectively, are given as

Liquids P and Q form an ideal solution. The vapour pressures of pure liquids P and Q at 80\(^{\circ}\)C are 300 mm and 100 mm of Hg, respectively. Suppose that the vapour above a solution composed of 1.0 mole of P and 1.0 mole of Q at 80\(^{\circ}\)C is collected and condensed. This condensate is then heated to 80\(^{\circ}\)C and vapour is again condensed to form a liquid R. What is the mole fraction of P in R?

A mixture contains 1 mole of volatile liquid A (\(P_A^{\circ} = 100\) mm Hg) and 3 moles of volatile liquid B (\(P_B^{\circ} = 80\) mm Hg). If the solution behaves ideally, the total vapour pressure of the distillate is

Pressure over an ideal binary liquid solution containing 10 moles each of liquid A and B is gradually decreased isothermally. At what pressure, half of the total amount of liquid will get converted into vapour? (\(P_A^{\circ} = 200\) torr, \(P_B^{\circ} = 100\) torr)

A liquid mixture of ‘A’ and ‘B’ (assume ideal solution) is placed in a cylinder and piston arrangement. The piston is slowly pulled out isothermally so that the volume of liquid decreases and that of the vapour increases. At the instant when the quantity of the liquid still remaining is negligibly small, the mole fraction of ‘A’ in the vapour is 0.4. If \(P_A^{\circ} = 0.4\) atm and \(P_B^{\circ} = 1.2\) atm at this temperature, then the total pressure at which the liquid has almost evaporated is

A liquid solution is formed by mixing 10 moles of aniline and 20 moles of phenol at a temperature where the vapour pressures of pure liquid aniline and phenol are 90 and 87 mm Hg, respectively. The possible vapour pressure of solution at that temperature is

At 35\(^{\circ}\)C, the vapour pressure of \(CS_2\) is 512 mm Hg and that of acetone \(CH_3COCH_3\) is 344 mm Hg. A solution of \(CS_2\) and acetone, in which the mole fraction of \(CS_2\) is 0.25 has a total vapour pressure of 600 mmHg. Which of the following statement about the solution of acetone and \(CS_2\) is true?
qOptions: A mixture of 100 ml of acetone and 100 ml of \(CS_2\) has a total volume of 200 ml.
When acetone and \(CS_2\) are mixed at 35\(^{\circ}\)C, heat is released.
When acetone and \(CS_2\) are mixed at 35\(^{\circ}\)C, heat is absorbed.
Raoult’s law is obeyed by both \(CS_2\) and acetone for the solution in which the mole fraction of \(CS_2\) is 0.25.

questions.qText: Mixing of the components in which of the following pair rises the temperature?

Water and chlorobenzene are immiscible liquids. Their mixture boils at 90\(^{\circ}\)C under a reduced pressure of \(9.031 \times 10^4\) Pa. The vapour pressure of pure water at 90\(^{\circ}\)C is \(7.031 \times 10^4\) Pa and the molecular mass of chlorobenzene is 112.5. On mass percent basis, chlorobenzene in the distillate is equal to
A liquid solvent is in equilibrium with its vapour. When a non-volatile solute is added to this liquid, the instant effect is the rate at which the solvent molecules leaves the

The vapour pressure of a solution of a non-volatile and non-electrolyte solute in a solvent is 95% of the vapour pressure of the pure solvent at the same temperature. If the molecular mass of the solvent is 0.3 times that of solute, then the mass ratio of solvent and solute is

The vapour pressure of a solvent is decreased by 10 mm of Hg when a non-volatile solute was added to the solvent. The mole fraction of solute in the solution is 0.2. What would be the mole fraction of solvent if decrease in vapour pressure is 20 mm of Hg?

Vapour pressure of a solution of 5 g of non-electrolyte in 100 g of water at a particular temperature is 2985 N/m\(^2\). If the vapour pressure of pure water at this temperature is 3000 N/m\(^2\), then the molecular mass of the solute is

The vapour pressure of pure benzene at a certain temperature is 0.85 bar. A non-volatile, non-electrolyte solid weighing 0.5 g is added to 39.0 g of benzene. The vapour pressure of the solution then is 0.845 bar. Molar mass of the solid substance is

A cylinder fitted with a movable piston contains liquid water in equilibrium with water vapour at 25\(^{\circ}\)C. Which of the following operation(s) results in a decrease in the equilibrium vapour pressure at 25\(^{\circ}\)C?
qOptions: Moving the piston downward for a short distance.
Removing a small amount of liquid water.
Dissolving some salt in the water.

questions.qText: Which is a colligative property?
The colligative properties of a solution may depend on

The vapour pressures of pure liquids A, B and C are 75, 22 and 10 torr, respectively. Which of the following is/are possible value(s) of vapour pressure of binary or ternary solutions having equimolar amounts of these liquids? Assume ideal behaviour for all possible solutions.
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct?
qOptions: Minimum boiling azeotropic mixture boils at temperature lower than either of the two pure components.
Maximum boiling azeotropic mixture boils at temperature higher than either of the two pure components.
Minimum boiling azeotropic mixture shows (+) ve deviation.
Maximum boiling azeotropic mixture shows (\(-\)) ve deviation.

questions.qText: Which of the following liquid pairs do not show positive deviation from Raoult’s law?
A mixture of liquids ‘A’ and ‘B’ in the molar ratio 1 : 2 forms a maximum boiling azeotrope. Identify the incorrect statement, if ‘A’ is more volatile. (Molar masses: A = 100, B = 50).
qOptions: A liquid solution of ‘A’ and ‘B’ having mass % of A = 50 will have vapours having mass % of A = 50.
A liquid solution of ‘A’ and ‘B’ having mass % of A > 50 will have vapours having mass % of A > 50.
A mixture of ‘A’ and ‘B’ in the molar ratio 1 : 3 can be separated into azeotropic mixture and pure ‘A’.
A mixture of ‘A’ and ‘B’ in the molar ratio 2 : 3 can be separated into azeotropic mixture and pure ‘A’.

questions.qText: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct?
qOptions: Two sucrose solution of same molality prepared in different solvent will have the same freezing point depression.
Osmotic pressure (\(\pi\)) of a solution is given by \(\pi = MRT\), where M is the molarity of the solution.
At same temperature, the correct order of osmotic pressure for 0.01 M aqueous solution of each compound is \(BaCl_2 > KCl > CH_3COOH >\) Sucrose.
Raoult’s law states that the vapour pressure of a component over a solution is proportional to its mole fraction.

questions.qText: In which of the following liquid pair, there is contraction in volume on mixing?
In a binary electrolyte (AB type), the observed lowering of vapour pressure as compared to the theoretically calculated one for non-electrolyte can never be
Comprehension Q. 29 to 30\n\nTwo solutions of non-volatile solutes ‘A’ and ‘B’ are prepared. The molar mass ratio is \(M_A : M_B = 1 : 3\). Both are prepared a 5% solution by mass in water.
The ratio of the freezing point depressions \(\Delta T_f (A) : \Delta T_f (B)\) of the solution is

If the above solutions are mixed to prepare two solutions \(S_1\) and \(S_2\), in the ratio 2 : 3 and 3 : 2, by volume, respectively, then what would be the ratio \(\Delta T_f (S_1) : \Delta T_f (S_2)\)?

Comprehension Q. 31 to 33\n\nLiquids A (molar mass = 100 g/mol and density = 1.25 g/ml) and B (molar mass = 50 g/mol and density = 1.0 g/ml) form an ideal solution. The molar volume of liquid ‘A’ increases by a factor of 3800 as it vaporizes at 27\(^{\circ}\)C and that of liquid ‘B’ increases by a factor of 7600 at 27\(^{\circ}\)C. A solution of liquids ‘A’ and ‘B’ at 27\(^{\circ}\)C has a vapour pressure of 54.0 torr. (R = 0.08 L·atm/K·mol).
The vapour pressure of pure liquid ‘A’ at 27\(^{\circ}\)C is
The vapour pressure of pure liquid ‘B’ at 27\(^{\circ}\)C is
The mole fraction of ‘A’ in the vapour above the solution in equilibrium at 27\(^{\circ}\)C is

Vapour pressure of solution containing 6 g of a non-volatile solute in 180 g water is 20 torr. If 1 mole of water is further added, then vapour pressure increases by 0.02 torr. The molar mass (in g/mol) of the non-volatile solute is

A solution containing compound ‘X’ in water and a solution containing glucose in water were put in a closed system. By doing this, some water vapour was removed from one solution and got condensed in the other. It is found that when both the solutions were at equilibrium vapour pressure, one solution contains 10% (w/w) of ‘X’ and the other 5% (w/w) glucose. The molar mass (in g/mol) of ‘X’ is

At 293 K, the vapour pressure of water is 2400 Pa and the vapour pressure of an aqueous urea solution is 2300 Pa. The osmotic pressure (in atm) of solution at 300 K, if the density of solution at this temperature is 1185 kg/m\(^3\), is (R = 0.08 L-atm/K-mol)

How many grams of ethylene glycol should be mixed in 795 g water to form an antifreeze solution that will not start to freeze until the temperature reaches −30\(^{\circ}\)C? (\(K_f\) for water = 1.86)
The mass of ice that will separate out on cooling a solution containing 50 g of ethylene glycol in 375 g water to −6.0\(^{\circ}\)C is (\(K_f\) for water = 1.86 K mol\(^{-1}\) kg)

A solution of 38.4 g of naphthalene in 185 g camphor depresses the freezing point of the latter by 13.5 K while 11.6 g of another substance when dissolved in 185 g of camphor gives depression of 9.0 K in freezing point. The molecular mass of the second substance is

Equal masses of two aqueous solutions, one of 3.6 g glucose per 100 g of water and the other of 3.6 g urea per 100 g of water are mixed. If the freezing point of resulting solution is −x\(^{\circ}\)C, then the value of ‘1000 x’ is (\(K_f\) of water = 1.86)

Safrole is contained in oil of sassafras and was once used to flavour root beer. A 2.4 mg sample of safrole was dissolved in 100.0 mg of diphenyl ether. The solution had a freezing of 25.64\(^{\circ}\)C. The freezing point of pure diphenyl ether is 26.84\(^{\circ}\)C and the freezing-point-depression constant \(K_f\) is 8.00\(^{\circ}\)C/m. The molecular mass of safrole is

A quantity of 2.0 g of benzoic acid dissolved in 26.0 g of benzene shows a depression in freezing point equal to 1.60 K. Molal depression constant of benzene is 4.88 K kg mol\(^{-1}\). The percentage association of the acid is

The value of ‘x’ g of a non-electrolytic compound (\(M = 200\)) is dissolved in 1 L of 0.05 M NaCl aqueous solution. The osmotic pressure of this solution is found to be 4.92 atm at 27\(^{\circ}\)C. Assume complete dissociation of NaCl and ideal behaviour for solution. The value of ‘x’ is (R = 0.082 L-atm mol\(^{-1}\) K\(^{-1}\))

At 20\(^{\circ}\)C, the vapour pressure of 0.1 molal aqueous solution of urea is 0.03 mm less than that of water and the vapour pressure of 0.1 molal solution of KCl is 0.0594 mm less than that of water. The apparent percentage dissociation of KCl in water at the given temperature is (Neglect the moles of solute particles in comparison to the moles of water in both solutions.)

A current of dry air was passed through a series of bulbs containing 1.25 g of a solute \(A_2B\) (molar mass = 90 g/mol) in 49 g of water and then through pure water. The loss in weight of the former series of bulbs was 0.98 g and in the later series 0.01 g. The percentage dissociation of solute is
A quantity of 75.2 g of phenol is dissolved in 1 kg of solvent of \(k_f = 14\). If the depression in freezing point is 7 K, then the percentage of phenol that dimerizes is

An aqueous solution contains 12% (w/w) \(MgSO_4\) and 9.5% (w/w) \(MgCl_2\). If the sulphate dissociates up to 80% and chloride dissociates up to 60%, the boiling point of solution (in Kelvin) is (\(K_b\) of water = 0.785 K·kg/mol)

When cells of the skeletal vacuole of a frog were placed in a series of NaCl solutions of different concentrations at 6\(^{\circ}\)C, it was observed microscopically that they remained unchanged in x% NaCl solution, it shrank in more concentrated solutions and swells in more dilute solutions. Water freezes from the x% salt solution at −0.40\(^{\circ}\)C. If the osmotic pressure of the cell cytoplasm at 6\(^{\circ}\)C is ‘y’ × 0.0821 atm, then the value of ‘y’ is (\(K_f = 1.86\) K mol\(^{-1}\) kg)

Match the columns.

Column I (Solute in water)
(A) KCl
(B) \(Na_2SO_4\)
(C) \(K_4[Fe(CN)_6]\)
(D) \(K_3[Fe(CN)_6]\)

Column II (Degree of dissociation to make van’t Hoff factor equal to 2)
(P) 0.33
(Q) 1.00
(R) 0.50
(S) 0.25

Match the columns.

Column I (Colligative properties)
(A) \(\Delta T_f = 0.3\,K_f\)
(B) \(\Delta T_b = 0.28\,K_b\)
(C) \(\pi = 0.198\,RT\)
(D) \(\dfrac{P^{\circ}-P}{P^{\circ}}\) (same for all below)

Column II (Aqueous solution; molality = molarity)
(P) 0.1 M–Ca(NO\(_3\))\(_2\)
(Q) 0.14 M–NaBr
(R) 0.1 M–MgCl\(_2\) (\(\alpha = 0.9\))
(S) 0.28 M–urea
(T) 0.1 M–HA (monobasic acid, \(K_a = 0.81\))
